Explanation: This spreadsheet contains the full list of variables and codes used in the ICASA standards. A general description of the standards is available at www.icasa.net/standards. The assumption is that the standards will evolve through time, especially through addition of new variables and codes.
Jeff White, Tony Hunt, Gerrit Hoogenboom, Cheryl Porter
jeff.white.az@gmail.com
Full name of variable, which may be used as a field name in databases
Short name of variable as used in the flat file (ASCII) implementation
Short name of variable that excludes non-standard characters (%, #)
Preferred order (position) within a table or sheet
Variant of a variable to be used as a database key
Full description of the variable
Units of measurement or type (e.g., text or code)
Formal variable type as specified in software or database
The highest level of aggregation in the ICASA Standard. May represent an experiment, collection of weather data or of soil profiles.
The middle level of aggregation. May represent metadata or major assemblages of data.
Name of data group where the variable is found in (but see "Sub-Group"). This corresponds roughly to tables that would be defined in a relational database.
If given, a possible sub-division of a group, which would be used to manage data in smaller blocks (e.g., as additional tables in a relational database).
Preferred order of datasets, subsets and groups within a database or workbook
Comment section for recording queries, suggestions for future versions of standards
Synonyms for codes that will still be recognized in DSSAT software
Which group a variable appears within a DSSAT file
The usual order of apearance within a group in a DSSAT file
Suggested minimum value for data validation
Suggested maximum for data validation
The corresponding variable (as Code_display version)
The actual code value.
A description of the code.
For arochemicals, describes how product is used (e.g., herbicide, growth regulator …)

Whether variable is part of ICASA standard
Type of code
The actual code value.
A description of the code.
For agrochemicals, target organisms or other use (e.g., defoliant)
Further explanation of the code or its usage

The actual three letter code value.
The common name of the crop
The latin binomial (scientific name)

Alternative uses of the crop (e.g., for maize, this might be forage)

The equivalent two-letter code used in DSSAT4.5
The equivalent name as used in APSIM models
The equivalent name as used in AgTrials
Whether the crop uses the C3, C4 or CAM mechanism
Whether the crop is typically grown as an annual, biennial or perennial.
Whether the primary response to photoperiod is short-day, long-day, etc.
Whether the crop has a vernalization requirement, although some genotypes may lack this response.
Which parts of the crop typically are harvested
What criteria are used to determine the harvest date. Typically a growth stage.
Whether the crop is capable of biological nitrogen fixation?
What part of the crop is usually planted (e.g., seed, eye-pieces of a tuber, stem cuttings)
What other parts of the crop may be used for planting
Hyperlink to the corresponding Wikipedia page.
Location of the crop within the DSSAT "tree" such as "Cereals" …
